def.dt: :a person who teaches and trains an athlete or performer a track/tennis star who has been working with a new coach a vocal/voice/drama coach
:a person who teaches and trains the members of a sports team and makes decisions about how the team plays during games a football/basketball/soccer coach
:a private teacher who gives someone lessons in a particular subject
:a large four-wheeled vehicle that is pulled by horses :carriage count In those days, people usually traveled long distances in coaches. noncount traveling by coach see also stagecoach

:a large bus with comfortable seating that is used for long trips count The company hired two coaches for the trip. noncount We traveled by coach to London. often used before another noun a coach driver/tour/party

:the section of least expensive seats on an airplane or train We reserved two seats in coach. I usually fly coach, but on this trip I'm flying first-class. often used before another noun coach fares/passengers/seats
:a separate section of a train a passenger coach [=(US) car, (Brit) carriage]
:to teach and train (an athlete or performer) + obj She coaches young actors/singers. He coaches the tennis star. no obj He coaches in singing.

:to teach, train, and direct (a sports team) + obj He has coached the team for several years. She coached the U.S. gymnastics team at the Olympics. He coaches football and basketball. [=he coaches football and basketball teams] no obj He has coached at the college level for many years.
:to teach (a student) privately rather than in a class

:to give (someone) instructions on what to do or say in a particular situation The lawyer admitted to coaching the witness. It was clear that the witness had been coached by her lawyer on how to answer the questions.

utxt.vi: She got into coaching a couple years ago.
He can pass the test with a little coaching.
The lawyer's coaching helped the witness.
